debutant.description: Difficult to get shots into play if opponent attacks serve. Long serves get looped, slightly high short serves get flipped or pushed aggressively.

No-spin serve is just as effective, if opponent isn't sure it's no-spin and it's very low. Mixing up backspin serves and no-spin serves (with other serves thrown in for surprise and variation) sets up big shots.
Meet the ball right off the bounce, with a light grazing motion. A short backspin serve is relatively easy to return short; if you push it long, opponent can attack, taking away big shots.
Placement and consistency are key. The placement will often set up follow-up attack. You don't need to flip every serve or short push for a winner.
If not overused, it'll catch opponents off guard, and set up big shots.
Loop first with a steady loop, forcing opponent into many mistakes. If power player makes one good block against opening loop, he'll often get shot he can go after on next shot.
Know when to play set-up shot and when to unleash big shot.
